title: Post-Conflict Reconnection
description: Explore how you reconnect and heal after disagreements.

questions.text: After a conflict is resolved, I need...
choices: Physical reconnection—a hug or closeness
Verbal reassurance that we're okay
Some time before I feel fully normal
To just move on and get back to regular life

therapeutic.rationale: Post-conflict reconnection needs vary. Physical-connectors need touch; verbal-reassurance seekers need words; time-needers process slowly; movers-on want normalcy. Mismatched needs delay healing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The physical-connector may feel rejected by the time-needer; the mover-on may feel the verbal-reassurer is dwelling. Share and honor each other's needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reconnection needs make post-conflict recovery seamless.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need after a conflict to feel reconnected? Are you getting it?

questions.text: The time it takes me to fully recover from conflict is usually...
choices: Quick—I bounce back fast once it's resolved
A few hours to settle back to normal
A day or more depending on the conflict
Varies a lot based on what happened

therapeutic.rationale: Recovery time varies by person and conflict. Quick-recoverers process fast; hours-needers take moderate time; day-plus needers process slow; variable types depend on severity. Expecting your partner to match your pace causes frustration.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The quick-recoverer may feel their slow partner holds grudges; the slow-recoverer may feel rushed. Honor each other's pace.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched recovery time creates aligned expectations about post-conflict normalcy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How long does it take you to fully recover from conflict? Is that okay with your partner?

questions.text: Something that helps me reconnect after conflict is...
choices: Doing something normal together
Talking about what happened and what we learned
Affection and physical closeness
Hearing that my partner still loves me

therapeutic.rationale: Reconnection methods vary. Normal-activity returners want routine; talkers want processing; affection-seekers want touch; love-affirmation seekers want words. Knowing what works for your partner helps you reconnect effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different methods may miss each other. The talker may not realize their partner is reconnecting through activity; the affection-seeker may not realize their partner is reconnecting through words.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reconnection methods make post-conflict healing natural.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you feel reconnected after a conflict? Have you told your partner?

questions.text: After conflict, I sometimes struggle with...
choices: Lingering hurt even after resolution
Anxiety that it might happen again
Feeling emotionally drained
I usually recover without struggle

therapeutic.rationale: Post-conflict struggles reveal vulnerabilities. Lingering-hurt types need more healing time; anxiety types need reassurance; drained types need rest; easy-recoverers have resilience. Naming struggles helps partners support recovery.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different struggles need different support. The lingering-hurt partner may need more processing; the anxious partner may need more reassurance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared struggles create mutual understanding about post-conflict challenges.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you struggle with after conflict? What would help?

questions.text: I know we've truly reconnected after conflict when...
choices: We can laugh together again
Physical affection feels natural again
We're talking normally without tension
I feel emotionally safe with them again

therapeutic.rationale: Reconnection indicators vary. Laughter-indicators notice humor return; affection-indicators notice touch ease; conversation-indicators notice normal talk; safety-feelers notice emotional security. Knowing your indicator helps you recognize reconnection.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different indicators may mean different timelines. One partner may feel reconnected before the other. Check in rather than assume.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared indicators mean you'll recognize reconnection at the same time.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you know when you've truly reconnected after a conflict?
